#1 String: When first I came to Louisville some pleasure there to find,
#2 String: A damsel there from Lexington was pleasing to my mind,

#1 String: Her rosy cheeks, her ruby lips like arrows pierced my breast.
#2 String: The name she bore was Flora, the Lily of the West.

#1 String: I courted lovely Flora some pleasure for to find,
#2 String: But she turned unto another man, which so distressed my mind,

#1 String: She robbed me of my liberty, deprived me of my rest.
#2 String: Then, go, my lovely Flora, the Lily of the West.

#1 String: Way down in yonder shady grove a man of high degree
#2 String: Conversing with my Flora there  it seemed so strange to me

#1 String: And the answer that she gave to him, it so did me oppress.
#2 String: I was betrayed by Flora, the Lily of the West.

#1 String: I stepped up to my rival, dagger in my hand,
#2 String: And seized him by the collar, boldly made him stand.

#1 String: Driven mad by desperation, I pierced him to the breast
#2 String: All this for lovely Flora, the Lily of the West.

#1 String: I had to stand my trial, I had to make my plea,
#2 String: They placed me in the witness box and then commenced on me.

#1 String: Although she swore my life away, deprived me of my rest,
#2 String: Still I love my faithless Flora, the Lily of the West.

#1 String: Gather 'round, you people, and a story I will tell
#2 String: About a brave, young Indian you should remember well

#1 String: From the tribe of Pima Indians, a proud and a peaceful band,
#2 String: They farmed the Phoenix Valley in Arizonaland.

#1 String: Down their ditches for a thousand years the sparkling water rushed
#2 String: Till the white man stole their water rights and the running water hushed.

#1 String: Now, Ira's folks were hungry and their farms were crops of weeds,
#2 String: But, when war came, he volunteered and forgot the white man's greed.

#1 String: Call him "Drunken" Ira Hayes, he won't answer anymore,
#2 String: Not the whiskeydrinking Indian or the marine who went to war,

#1 String: Yes, call him "Drunken" Ira Hayes, he won't answer anymore,
#2 String: Not the whiskeydrinking Indian or the marine who went to war.

#1 String: They started up Iwo Jima hill two hundred and fifty men,
#2 String: But only twentyseven lived to walk back down that hill again

#1 String: And, when the fight was over and Old Glory raised,
#2 String: One of the men who held it high was the Indian, Ira Hayes.

#1 String: Call him "Drunken" Ira Hayes, he won't answer anymore,
#2 String: Not the whiskeydrinking Indian or the marine who went to war,

#1 String: Call him "Drunken" Ira Hayes, he won't answer anymore,
#2 String: Not the whiskeydrinking Indian or the marine who went to war.

#1 String: Now, Ira returned a hero, celebrated throughout the land,
#2 String: He was wined and speeched and honored, everybody shook his hand,

#1 String: But he was just a Pima Indian  no money, no crops, no chance
#2 String: And at home nobody cared what Ira done and the wind did the Indians' dance.

#1 String: Call him "Drunken" Ira Hayes, he won't answer anymore,
#2 String: Not the whiskeydrinking Indian or the marine who went to war,

#1 String: Call him "Drunken" Ira Hayes, he won't answer anymore,
#2 String: Not the whiskeydrinking Indian or the marine who went to war.

#1 String: And Ira started drinking hard, jail was often his home
#2 String: They let him raise the flag there and lower it like you'd throw a dog a bone.

#1 String: He died drunk early one morning alone in the land he'd fought to save,
#2 String: Two inches of water in a lonely ditch was the grave for Ira Hayes.

#1 String: I knew a man, Bojangles, and he'd dance for you in wornout shoes
#2 String: Silver hair, ragged shirt, and baggy pants, that old soft shoe.

#1 String: He'd jump so high, he'd jump so high, then he'd lightly touch down.
#2 String: Mr. Bojangles, Mr. Bojangles, dance!

#1 String: I met him in a cell in New Orleans  I was down and out,
#2 String: He looked to me to be the eyes of age as he spoke right out.

#1 String: He talked of life, he talked of life, laughed and slapped his leg a step.
#2 String: Mr. Bojangles, Mr. Bojangles, dance!

#1 String: He said the name, Bojangles, and he danced a lick all across the cell,
#2 String: He grabbed his pants for a better stance, oh, he jumped so high and clicked up his heels.

#1 String: He let go a laugh, he let go a laugh, shook back his clothes all around.
#2 String: Mr. Bojangles, Mr. Bojangles, dance! Yeah, dance!

#1 String: He danced for those at minstrel shows and county fairs throughout the South,
#2 String: He spoke with tears of fifteen years of how his dog and him just traveled all about.

#1 String: His dog up and died, he up and died, and after twenty years he still grieves.
#2 String: Mr. Bojangles, Mr. Bojangles, dance!

#1 String: He said, "I dance now at every chance at honkytonks for drinks and tips,
#2 String: But most of the time I spend behind these county bars 'cause I drinks a bit."

#1 String: He shook his head and then he shook his head, I heard someone ask him, "Please,
#2 String: Mr. Bojangles, Mr. Bojangles, dance!

#1 String: Dance!
#2 String: Mr. Bojangles, dance!"

#1 String: There's this book coming out and they asked me to write, uh, something about Woody, uh, sort of like, "What does Woody Guthrie mean to you in 25 words?" And, uh, I couldn't do it, I wrote out five pages. And, uh, I have it hereit's, uhhave it here by accident, actually. Ha, but, but, uh, I'dI'd like to say this out loud, so, uh, if you could sorta roll along with this thing here, this is called "Last Thoughts on Woody Guthrie".
#2 String: Um, when your head gets twisted and your mind grows numb,

#1 String: When you think you're too old, too young, too smart, or too dumb,
#2 String: When you're lagging behind and losing your pace

#1 String: In the slowmotion crawl or life's busy race,
#2 String: No matter what you're doing, if you start giving up,

#1 String: If the wine don't come to the top of your cup,
#2 String: If the wind got you sideways with one hand holding on

#1 String: And the other starts slipping and the feeling is gone,
#2 String: And your trainengine fire needs a new spark to catch it,

#1 String: And the wood's easy finding but you're lazy to fetch it,
#2 String: And your sidewalk starts curling and the street gets too long,

#1 String: And you start walking backwards though you know that it's wrong,
#2 String: And lonesome comes up as down goes the day,

#1 String: And tomorrow's morning seems so far away,
#2 String: And you feel the reins from your pony are slipping,

#1 String: And your rope is asliding 'cause your hands are dripping,
#2 String: And your sundecked desert and evergreen valleys

#1 String: Turn to brokendown slums and trashcan alleys,
#2 String: And your sky cries water and your drainpipe's apouring,

#1 String: And the lightning's aflashing and the thunder's acrashing,
#2 String: And the windows are rattling and breaking, your rooftops're shaking,

#1 String: And your whole world's aslamming and banging,
#2 String: And your minutes of sun turn to hours of storm,

#1 String: And to yourself you sometimes say,
#2 String: "I never knew it was gonna be this way.

#1 String: Why didn't they tell me the day I was born?"
#2 String: And you start getting chills and you're jumping from sweat,

#1 String: And you're looking for something you ain't quite found yet,
#2 String: And you're kneedeep in dark water with your hands in the air,

#1 String: And the whole world's watching with the "windowpeek" stare,
#2 String: And your good gal leaves and she's long gone aflying,

#1 String: And your heart feels sick like fish when they're frying,
#2 String: And your jackhammer falls from your hands to your feet

#1 String: But you need it badly and it lays on the street,
#2 String: And your bell's banging loudly but you can't hear its beat,

#1 String: And you think your ears mighta been hurt
#2 String: Or your eyes've turned filthy from the sightblinding dirt,

#1 String: And you figured you failed in yesterday's rush
#2 String: When you were faked out and fooled while facing a four flush

#1 String: And all the time you're holding the three queens,
#2 String: It's making you mad, it's making you mean,

#1 String: Like in the middle of Life magazine,
#2 String: Bouncing around a pinball machine,

#1 String: And there's something on your mind that you wanna be saying,
#2 String: That somebody someplace oughtta be hearing,

#1 String: But it's trapped on your tongue and sealed in your head
#2 String: And it bothers you badly when you're laying in bed,

#1 String: And, no matter how you try, you just can't say it,
#2 String: And you're scared to your soul you just might forget it,

#1 String: And your eyes get swimmy from the tears in your head,
#2 String: And your pillows of feathers turn to blankets of lead,

#1 String: And the lion's mouth opens and you're staring at his teeth,
#2 String: And his jaws start closing with you underneath,

#1 String: And you're flat on your belly with your hands tied behind,
#2 String: And you wish you'd never taken that last detour sign,

#1 String: You say to yourself, "Just what am I doing
#2 String: On this road I'm walking, on this trail I'm turning,

#1 String: On this curve I'm hanging, on this pathway I'm strolling,
#2 String: In this space I'm taking, in this air I'm inhaling?

#1 String: Am I mixed up too much? Am I mixed up too hard?
#2 String: Why am I walking? Where am I running?

#1 String: What am I saying? What am I knowing
#2 String: On this guitar I'm playing, on this banjo I'm flailing,

#1 String: On this mandolin I'm strumming, in this song I'm singing,
#2 String: In the tune I'm humming, in the words that I'm thinking,

#1 String: In the words that I'm writing, in this ocean of hours I'm all the time drinking?
#2 String: Who am I helping? What am I breaking?

#1 String: What am I giving? What am I taking?"
#2 String: But you try with your whole soul,

#1 String: Best never to think these thoughts and never to let them kinda thoughts gain ground,
#2 String: Or make your heart pound, but, then again, you know when they're around,

#1 String: Just waiting for a chance to slip and drop down
#2 String: 'Cause sometimes you hear 'em when the night times come creeping

#1 String: And you fear they might catch you sleeping,
#2 String: And you jump from your bed from the last chapter of dreaming,

#1 String: And you can'tyou remember for the best of your thinking
#2 String: If that was you in the dream that was screaming,

#1 String: And you know that it's something special you're needing,
#2 String: You know there's no drug that'll do for the healing,

#1 String: And no liquor in the land to stop your brain from bleeding,
#2 String: Need something specialneed something special, alright,

#1 String: You need a fastflying train on a tornado track,
#2 String: To shoot you someplace and shoot you back,

#1 String: You need a cyclone wind on a steam engine howler
#2 String: That's been banging and booming and blowing forever,

#1 String: That knows your troubles a hundred times over,
#2 String: You need a Greyhound bus that don't bar no race,

#1 String: That won't laugh at your looks, your voice, or your face,
#2 String: And, by any number of bets in the book,

#1 String: Will be rolling long after the bubblegum craze,
#2 String: You need something to open up a new door,

#1 String: To show you something you seen before
#2 String: But overlooked a hundred times or more,
